text:
Q: IntelliJ IDEA blocks first character after switching keyboard layout (Windows beep sound) A:

I managed to reproduce the issue and created a usability problem report on YouTrack: https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IJPL-223992. Please vote for it and follow for updates.

It looks like the IDE recognizes the key combination as a keyboard shortcut attempt instead of two separate operations: switch keyboard layout + start typing text in the editor.

Q: Programming a NRF52840 MCU with PlatformIO and BlackMagicProbe A:

I solved my issue, it was a faulty MCU chip.

Q: Git rebase flow A:

Rebasing public branches can be useful, but it has to be done in controlled manner. With such approach the history is kept from deployment perspective, rather than developer perspective. Examples and scripting can be found here https://github.com/k4hvd1/rebaser-flow.

Q: Confused about implementing degree() and incident_edges() for topological sort in Python A:

This follows Kahn's Algorithm (BFS-Based).

First of all, according to the textbook, as per the Graph object, you are not supposed to create the outgoing and ingoing dictionaries, but instead store pairs of edges as it is.
HOWEVER, it is easier to modify your current code by replacing e with v , so it becomes for v in g.incident_edges(u): , and completely removing v = e.opposite(u) . (It also makes more sense to call incident_edges something like neighbor_vertices if you follow this.)

Also, I will reply the questions based on your current code.

1. I don't know where you got the idea of incoming from, but considering how it is False in the textbook, it suggests that it follows this (scroll to bottommost) > https://csiflabs.cs.ucdavis.edu/%5C~tyfeng/ecs34/C++/graphs.html which means that it's instead meant to be outgoing , so when it is False it reports the number of incoming edges. So, something like:

def degree(self, u, out): # remember 'outgoing' variable already exists, so calling it 'out' here.
    if (out):
        return len(self.outgoing[u])
    return len(self.incoming[u])

2. incident_edges (or neighbor_vertices I suggest) will be like:

def incident_edges(self, u):
        return self.outgoing[u]

If you want to follow the textbook, you need to loop through all the edges, then return the edges that start with u .

3. Your understanding ofEdge.opposite(self, u) is correct, it just doesn't make sense when you already have incoming and outgoing like that. According to your textbook, if there's an edge e =("Wash Rice", "Soak Rice") then e.opposite("Soak Rice") returns "Wash Rice" and vice versa.

4. By running the implementation of the algorithm at https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/dsa/topological-sorting-indegree-based-solution/ , yes, it returns an incomplete list. Try in that website with fx:

addEdge(adj, 0, 1)
addEdge(adj, 2, 1)
addEdge(adj, 2, 3)
addEdge(adj, 4, 5)
addEdge(adj, 1, 5)
addEdge(adj, 5, 2)

It only prints 0 4 .

Hope these make sense, otherwise you are welcome to ask for further clarification :)

Q: package e1071 tuning the best model for regression and classification A:

This really doesn't seem to be a specific programming question. If you want advice about your data analysis, I seems like https://stats.stackexchange.com/ would be a better place to ask.

Q: Detection of Shopify search forms A:

I looked at 10 stores from their example store list and there doesn't seem to be a consistent rule. What I found is, the following:

Site input-name input-type distinctive selector autocomplete="off"
KirrinFinch q text .quick-search__input yes
Rothys - text .input__control_s yes
BeefCakeSwimwear q search .search-input > input yes
Suta st text .st-search-bar > input yes
Uppercase Magazine q search .site-header__search-input yes
HiutDenim q search none yes
TenTree - text #search-inputbox yes
MaquireShoes q search - yes
TheOutrage q search .search-bar--modal > input yes
AdoredVintage q search #Search yes

So there's no clear schema, but most search bars will have name="q" and autocomplete="off"

Q: How to calculate code metrics in Visual Studio Code? A:

I am using the latest version of VS Code. There is no Analyse Tab in it. I installed the CodeMetrics extension from MarketPlace. It worked out of the box. Though there are a few things you can check:

  1. Whether Codemetrics › Basics: Diagnostics Enabled is checked in CodeMetrics settings.
  2. Your CodeMetrics is configured for your language and requirements are configured as per your need. Most of the Lua configurations are present along with the score they add to the complexity. These scores are subjective

Example: I had a function which has 1 if, 3 else if blocks, and 1 else block. All of which adds 1 to complexity - So the total complexity of my function was 5.

That's all
